sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Hypertension: initial, 5 mg ORALLY twice daily
  • Hypertension: titrate to maintenance, may increase weekly or monthly to 20-75 mg ORALLY daily (divide 2-4 times daily); MAX dose, 400 mg/day

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and effectiveness not established in children

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: CrCl 30-60 mL/min, 5 mg ORALLY daily
  • renal impairment: CrCl less than 30 mL/min, 5 mg ORALLY every 2 days
  • renal impairment: titration, dosage increases should not be made in less than 7-14 days

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• congestive heart failure
  • hypersensitivity to guanadrel
  • pheochromocytoma
  • monoamine-oxidase inhibitor use (concurrent or within 1 wk of use)

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• anesthesia (discontinue 48-72 hr prior to surgery)
  • asthma
  • cerebral vascular disease
  • coronary artery disease
  • myocardial infarction, recent
  • orthostatic hypotension
  • peptic ulcer disease
  • renal impairment

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Guanadrel: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
GUANETHIDINE
OVERDOSE: Dizziness, blurred vision, bradycardia, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea are commonly reported. Profound hypotension (especially orthostatic) and shock are the most severe signs of toxicity following overdosage. ADVERSE EFFECTS: A transient episode of early hypertension may be noted prior to the onset of hypotension. Hypertensive crisis due to sensitization by guanethidine to some indirect acting sympathomimetics (metaraminol and ephedrine) may occur.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
GUANETHIDINE
  • Decontamination: Consider activated charcoal if patient is able to protect their airway.
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Hypotensive episode: IV 0.9% NaCl 10 to 20 mL/kg, dopamine, norepinephrine. Consider central venous pressure or pulmonary artery monitoring.
  • Malignant hypertension: Nitroprusside - Symptomatic hypertension episodes should be treated with nitroprusside (initiate 1 microgram/kilogram/minute by intravenous infusion and adjust to control blood pressure; average dose 3 micrograms/kilogram/minute).
  • Bradycardia: Bradycardia associated with hypotension may be treated with atropine.
  • Diarrhea: Severe or persistent diarrhea should be treated with anticholinergic agents and maintenance of fluid and electrolyte balance.
  • Monitoring of patient: Continuous cardiac monitoring is recommended. Monitor central venous or pulmonary wedge pressure in severely hypotensive patients. No specific lab work (CBC, urinalysis, electrolytes) is needed unless otherwise indicated. Due to the prolonged duration of action, symptomatic patients should be admitted, with continuous cardiac monitoring. Normal homeostatic mechanisms gradually return over approximately 72 hours. Asymptomatic patients should be observed with cardiac monitoring for a minimum of 6 hours after overdose.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
GUANETHIDINE
TOXICITY: Range of toxicity is not well described. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: ADULT - 10 to 50 mg orally daily; may increase in 10 to 25 mg increments at 5 to 7 day intervals; MAX dose, 100 mg orally per day. PEDIATRIC: Not FDA approved in children.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to rise slowly from a sitting/supine position, as drug may cause orthostatic hypotension.
  • Patient should avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause dizziness or somnolence.
  • This drug may cause edema, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, or sexual dysfunction.
  • Patient should not use guanadrel sulfate concomitantly or within 1 wk of taking MAO inhibitors.
  • Advise patient to avoid alcohol while taking this drug.
